Message From The Mensch
Good morning, my name is Michael
Wallk. I have decided, with my running
mate Amir Halevy, to seize the Student
Council presidency and vice-presidency at
this time. I will now issue a brief comment
on the actions that forced us to take this
necessary step.
Amir and I have been frustrated by the
divisiveness that has marked Council
proceedings this year. On each of the
issues facing it—the new constitution, the
Spring Fair date, and the performance of
its committees--the Council has brazenly
ignored overwhelming student indifference
and has managed to fabricate several
opinions on each topic, leading to lengthy
debate. The approach to solving problems-the recognition of two and sometimes even
more sides to an issue--is clearly serving
only to reinforce the Council's divisiveness.
Last week, Amir and I attempted to
mend these cracks by announcing our
candidacy along a "party line." We agreed
to work in tandem and tried to emphasize
the beauty of this system to the students:
there would be no further divisions of the
Council. A single decision would be made

and stuck with. I wanted to take the
politics out of it.
But the old order sought, characteristically, to resist new blood. In an action
which was purely sour grapes, the Elections
Commission proposed extending the filing
deadline for new candidates. The motion,
which was easily passed amidst the usual
bickering, could have the effect of introducing even more fragmentation and
factionalism by widening the spectrum of
candidates and issues.
That did it. The final and ultimate
authority of the Council had been forever
undermined by this false courtship with the
democratic process. The last nail on the
coffin came later that evening when the
Council unwisely chose to consult the
student body before passing a resolution on
El Salvador.
I know the Council's duties intimately; I
have been running for president for the
past three years. There is no place on the
Council for embarassingly insincere displays of interest in real issues. Our role,
obviously, is and always has been solely to
discuss our own legitimacy.

renewed religious persecution of

mass exodus from France to
England.

THE FUTURE OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESS
According to Jack Goellner the university
presses are entering a new era of cooperation.
Goellner forsees increasing cooperation among
university presses in virtually all aspects of
publication except editorial. Goellner feels that
Johns Hopkins Press has done more not only
to preach but practice cooperation than other
university presses.
Twelve different university presses use
Hopkins' data processing system. Five other
university presses store their books in the
Hopkins Press warehouse in Baltimore and four
other university presses do their ordering
through Johns Hopkins. The presses of Cornell,
California, and Johns Hopkins universities have
formed CCJ Ltd., which operates out of London
and sells books to foreign markets. Johns

mythological mood is undermined. The
crucial mystical scene in the novel is the
rape: Tess falls asleep in the misty
forest and wakes up already violated.
Naturally, this would be difficult to
deliver visually, especially to a modern
audience who have benefited from the
demystification of their sexuality. Polanski's solution reveals his indecision.

seduced, and resists again until Alec
finally has his way with her. The flacidity of their bodies as they struggle mirrors
the flacidity of the director.
In the novel, Alec's character
grows more complex. After the rape
he converts to Christianity, and his
continuing lust for Tess becomes an
internal struggle between his new piety
and an older primal self. Polanski ho-

mogenizes his character so that he is only
a blend of sly lover and Snidely Whiplash.

content, brought out through the authorial omniscience, is lost in the prolonged

as a result, the psychological connections
between characters, and between Tess

times her whimsical fancy would intensify natural processes around her till they

buds and bark of the winter twigs, were
formulae of bitter reproach. A wet day
was the expression of irremediable grief."

fetishized appearance of things. Viewers

Message From The Mensch
Good morning, my name is Michael
Wallk. I have decided, with my running
mate Amir Halevy, to seize the Student
Council presidency and vice-presidency at
this time. I will now issue a brief comment
on the actions that forced us to take this
necessary step.
Amir and I have been frustrated by the
divisiveness that has marked Council
proceedings this year. On each of the
issues facing it—the new constitution, the
Spring Fair date, and the performance of
its committees--the Council has brazenly
ignored overwhelming student indifference
and has managed to fabricate several
opinions on each topic, leading to lengthy
debate. The approach to solving problems-the recognition of two and sometimes even
more sides to an issue--is clearly serving
only to reinforce the Council's divisiveness.
Last week, Amir and I attempted to
mend these cracks by announcing our
candidacy along a "party line." We agreed
to work in tandem and tried to emphasize
the beauty of this system to the students:
there would be no further divisions of the
Council. A single decision would be made

and stuck with. I wanted to take the
politics out of it.
But the old order sought, characteristically, to resist new blood. In an action
which was purely sour grapes, the Elections
Commission proposed extending the filing
deadline for new candidates. The motion,
which was easily passed amidst the usual
bickering, could have the effect of introducing even more fragmentation and
factionalism by widening the spectrum of
candidates and issues.
That did it. The final and ultimate
authority of the Council had been forever
undermined by this false courtship with the
democratic process. The last nail on the
coffin came later that evening when the
Council unwisely chose to consult the
student body before passing a resolution on
El Salvador.
I know the Council's duties intimately; I
have been running for president for the
past three years. There is no place on the
Council for embarassingly insincere displays of interest in real issues. Our role,
obviously, is and always has been solely to
discuss our own legitimacy.

THE FUTURE OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESS
According to Jack Goellner the university
presses are entering a new era of cooperation.
Goellner forsees increasing cooperation among
university presses in virtually all aspects of
publication except editorial. Goellner feels that
Johns Hopkins Press has done more not only
to preach but practice cooperation than other
university presses.
Twelve different university presses use
Hopkins' data processing system. Five other
university presses store their books in the
Hopkins Press warehouse in Baltimore and four
other university presses do their ordering
through Johns Hopkins. The presses of Cornell,
California, and Johns Hopkins universities have
formed CCJ Ltd., which operates out of London
and sells books to foreign markets. Johns
